subtitle: [Music]
New Thinking Allowed. Conversations on the
leading edge
of knowledge and discovery with
parapsychologist
Jeffrey Mishlove.
Hello, and welcome. I’m Jeffrey Mishlove.
Today I'd like to share
with you some memories from the happiest
day of my life. That would have been
- I've never doubted it - August 27,
1978. It's the day I married my wife
Janelle. You can see her here. It was
a hippie wedding. We made garlands of
flowers for all of the women
who attended. My mom and dad were there.
My dad,
who's reading a quote from Swami
Muktananda.
He didn't really understand it and could
hardly pronounce
the name but my sister had put him up to
it.
And my mom who was a yoga teacher at
the time. Here's a picture of my
friend Saul-Paul
Sirag. He's still a good friend of mine,
there's six
interviews with him on the New Thinking
Allowed channel.
And here's his girlfriend from back then
Barbara
Honegger. She got a master's degree in
parapsychology from John F.
Kennedy university back in the day when
I was on the faculty, they were
offering that program.
Subsequently she got a job working in
the White House
and eventually left the White House and
became a conspiracy theorist. Her book
October Surprise is a classic
of conspiracy theory.
This is a picture of my friend Tommy
Dees. He
was a fine artist and a real
troublemaker because he was always
provoking the edges of what was
acceptable.
He got beaten up severely by the police
at Hayward State College, or University,
where he
was an art student at the time.
They beat him up and then they charged
him with
resisting arrest. I attended the
hearing because he got off, his
lawyer pointed out that the police had
the intention of beating him up
right from the start. Now,
this as I say, it was a hippie wedding
that was held outdoors at the
Westerbeck Ranch which was affiliated
with the Esalen
Institute. They had a big swimming
pool and I have to say,
much to the horror of my father who
was a
conservative midwestern businessman,
there was
nudity. People were undressing and
swimming in the pool.
Here's a picture of Alan Vaughan
with his daughter Lauren who was one
year old at the time.
Alan was a dear friend, a gifted psychic,
an author and also a parapsychology
researcher, which is a rare combination.
His books
include Patterns of Prophecy, Incredible
Coincidence
, Dream Telepathy, The Edge of Tomorrow,
Doorways to Higher Consciousness.
Here's an image of Jana Janus. Now, Janna
was also a gifted psychic and one of the
people
who really drew me to the field of
parapsychology
because she had this incredible talent
for finding
four leaf clovers. She would hear a
little voice
that says, “Pick me, pick me,” and she'd
reach down and there'd be a four-leaf
clover.
She collected hundreds of them.
For our wedding Jana gave Janelle and I
a gift of many dozen mounted
four leaf clovers.
This image is our dear friend
Debbie Swackhammer who's actually
known now as
Deborah Hayden. She became a writer
eventually. She wrote a wonderful book
called The Pox
in which she looked at the role of
syphilis
and how it affected creative geniuses.
I'd love to be able to get Debbie into
the studio for an interview. It would be
fascinating. Here are two friends Dino D.
Felipe on the left and Ellis Gold
on the right. Dino was a broadway
producer. He's written a
musical comedy called Stardom.
You can see it on his website today.
Here's my friend Gary Zukav
who is the author of The Seat of the
Soul,
many books about the soul and also
a wonderful book about physics in
consciousness called
The Dancing Wu Li Masters. Both of these
books were best
sellers. Gary and I traveled together
to Machu Picchu
in Peru. It was a wonderful trip.
This person, Henry Dakin,
passed away in 2010 but just
this year a book about him was published,
Henry
S. Dakin: From Physics to Metaphysics &
Guns to Toys. He was a very important
person
in the citizens diplomacy movement,
the movement that sort of created
a detente and a breakthrough between
the United States
and Russia. He did many
things like that. He was also a big
sponsor of parapsychology and he
provided
a workspace for me at a place called
the Washington Research Center which
he put together. That's where I
really did
most of my doctoral work when I was a
student in parapsychology because
I was without a department. The
university provided me with very few
resources but fortunately the community
in the San Francisco bay area
made up for that. For example, here
you see Lee Sannella and Freda Morris. Lee
was the author of Kundalini, Psychosis
or Transcendence, the first book really
to look at
the question of people who are
having a spiritual breakthrough and
having all kinds of strange symptoms
that are now
understood to be part of a syndrome
associated with kundalini.
Lee, who was an ophthalmologist, is really
the first person to identify that.
Freda Morris, his girlfriend at the
time,
was a hypnotherapist who wrote a book
about hypnosis.
My friend Rich Hisler was sort of a
beatnik poet. He became an
off off broadway playwright.
I think he's mostly known now for a play
called
The Greatest Sex of the 20th Century.
My friends Stan Russell and Lana
Clark.
I used to hang out with them a good deal
in the years before I got married.
Stan would teach workshops on tantric
sex
and his girlfriend Lana
developed a form of psychotherapy she
called holistic psychotherapy.
This picture of Joe di Ambria. Joe was
a student of mine when I was doing
my doctoral research in parapsychology. I
set up a program
to train remote viewing back
in 1977. I was still a graduate student
when I got married in ‘78,
finishing up writing my dissertation. And
you know
Joe was a very talented remote viewer.
There he is with his wife. He also
volunteered to work with me
and to try and organize the files that I
had on Ted Owens,
The PK Man. He reported something
quite extraordinary. He had the files
neatly organized in a file box in his
living room.
When he woke up the next morning they
were scattered all over the floor as if
a poltergeist
had attacked. This person
is my friend Jim Driscoll who is my
college roommate as an undergraduate at
the University
of Wisconsin. You'll find six
interviews with him today on the New
Thinking Allowed channel.
After Janelle and I
recited our vows, which we wrote
ourselves, we designed the wedding
ceremony.
We had some doves, we were going to
release these
doves to show that we could be married
and still have
our own individual freedom. And
the funniest thing, half of the doves
didn't want to fly away.
We later learned that their wings
had actually been
clipped and the people who sold us the
doves were there to collect them
after the wedding ceremony so they
could sell them again
for the next wedding, I guess. We were
surprised and it was kind of funny.
But I have to say this, it was indeed the
happiest day of my life. I'm so
grateful to be able to look back and say
I've been married for 42 years
to Janelle Barlow. It's been not only a
successful marriage but for those of you
who appreciate New Thinking Allowed, who
appreciate
whatever contributions I've been able to
make to your lives, I can tell you this
- none of it would have been possible
without her support
and her love. I'm so grateful. I can
tell you this.
Marrying this woman was the best
decision
I ever made. Let me ask you
in closing, what was the happiest day
of your life? I'll leave you with that
question.
Thank you for being with me and let
me also
suggest to you that you log into the New
Thinking Allowed dot org
website, that's the New Thinking Allowed
Foundation,
where you can subscribe to our free
weekly newsletter.
[Music]
